choices.B: An administrator creates a new mail flow rule.
choices.E: A user purges messages from their mailbox.
choices.D: A user delegates permissions to their mailbox.
choices.A: An administrator creates a new Microsoft SharePoint site collection.
choices.C: A user shares a Microsoft SharePoint folder with an external user.

discussion.content: From the link: "Although mailbox audit logging on by default is enabled for all organizations, only users with E5 licenses will return mailbox audit log events in audit log searches in the Security & Compliance Center or via the Office 365 Management Activity API by default." As the question says they only have E3 licenses, user actions on their mailboxes are not logged by default.

Selected Answer: ABC
testing voting comment
end of test.
ABC - mailbox audit only goes for E5 users

Admin activity in Exchange Online (Exchange admin audit logging)
Admin activity in SharePoint Online
User activity in SharePoint Online and OneDrive for Business

Answer should be ABC, since user actions are not logged by default with an E3 license as described before. Actions ABC are audited as described on https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/search-the-audit-log-in-security-and-compliance?view=o365-worldwide#audited-activities

Searched in the referenced doc and found "Created Site Collection", "Added delegate mailbox permissions" and "Removed delegate mailbox permissions", "Purged messages from the mailbox". So the answer should be A, D, E.

comments.content:
Took another look. Answer should be A, B, C, since mailbox auditing not enabled for users with E3 license by default.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/enable-mailbox-auditing?view=o365-worldwide#more-information

discussion.content:
Just as additional info: Mailbox auditing can be activated for E3 as well (but it's not default).
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/enable-mailbox-auditing?view=o365-worldwide#more-information

questions.question_text:
You create a new Microsoft 365 subscription and assign Microsoft 365 E3 licenses to 100 users.
From the Security & Compliance admin center, you enable auditing.
You are planning the auditing strategy.
Which three activities will be audited by default? Each correct answer presents a complete solution.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

discussion.content: Answers seem correct based on settings.
Correct answer
Correct

I think that the second statement is “No”, from the provided link, you can find: “For standard retention labels (they don't mark items as a record or regulatory record) -> Admins and end users can manually change or remove an existing retention label that's applied on content.”
Was in Exam today 20 Aug 2022

Provided answers are correct
Came on exam 09-05-2022

Selected Answer: B
Defender for Identity provides three types of security groups: Azure ATP (Workspace name) Administrators, Azure ATP (Workspace name) Users, and Azure ATP (Workspace name) Viewers. 

Update Defender for Identity Configuration - Sensors (download, regenerate key, configure, delete) is not available to the "Users" group, only "Admin".

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/defender-for-identity/role-groups

comments.content: The ones who could are users 1,3 and 4.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
No.

Defender for Identity provides three types of security groups: Azure ATP (instance name) Administrators, Azure ATP (instance name) Users, and Azure ATP (instance name) Viewers.

The 'User' group :

Update Defender for Identity Configuration - Sensors (download, regenerate key, configure, delete) for 'Users' : Not available

The questions groups have "Defender for Identity Contoso {Administrator/Users}." Now, Defender for Identity is what Azure ATP was rebranded to. However the groups that are created are still using the "Azure ATP {tenant name} {Administrator/Viewers/Users}" format.

I don't know if this question is trying to trip you up with the naming of the groups, or if the question was written incorrectly by ExamTopics. Maybe It's an old question? I'm not sure. 

Given the information from my tenant, and what is in the question, the answer is No. Unless the question is old. Then the groups follow the current format, then the questions answer is Yes.

If you're taking the 101 exam anytime after 2/1/2022 I'm betting the groups will follow the "Azure ATP {tenant name} {Administrator/Viewers/Users}" format.

Clear as mud.

Answer is outright Yes
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/defender-for-identity/role-groups

Selected Answer: B
In my Tenant the Groups are named „Azure ATP %tenantname% Administrator“ and so on.. Can anyone confirm? Then it would clearly be B.
Seems obvious to me that the answer is YES as User 1, 3, or 4 could have carried out the task according to https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/defender-for-identity/role-groups
This one is a bit confusing. If I call a group Administrators, it doesn't mean that it has admin privilege unless that's the account type that I set. So "A" may not necessarily be correct?

comments.content: agree, as it stands that answer is not correct as it says the user has no role
Yeah the wording is ambiguous and as it's written the answer is no, but I bet the actual exam has a different heading in the 2nd column.

discussion.content:
Note - Azure Advanced Threat Protection (ATP) has been rebranded as Defender for Identity. Previous versions of this question reference Azure ATP rather than Defender for Identity.

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/defender-for-identity/what-is

discussion.content: B. NO - Topic3, Question 48, 57, &58 pose this same question with alternative solutions. The answer is in question 48. The PowerShell command for New-ComplianceSecurityFilter must originate from the M365 Compliance Command Center. “Use the New-ComplianceSecurityFilter cmdlet to create compliance security filters in the Microsoft 365 compliance center. These filters allow specified users to search only a subset of mailboxes and SharePoint Online or OneDrive for Business sites in your Microsoft 365 organization”. Reference: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/exchange/new-compliancesecurityfilter?view=exchange-ps

Answer is correct: 
B: No

This will need to be done in the Compliance Portal

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/assign-ediscovery-permissions?view=o365-worldwide
